Aliens could be chatting with each other in plain sight using light flashes like fireflies, scientists say
Source: AOL.com    Published: 2026-01-07 05:34:25

News / Email / Weather / Video Advertisement For premium support please call: For premium support please call: Advanced aliens could be chatting with each other using light flashes in plain sight, similar to how fireflies communicate, according to a new study that could lead to new approaches in finding extraterrestrial civilisations. Until now, astronomers have mainly been trying to detect advanced aliens by looking for odd radio signals from distant planets and peculiar heat signatures indicative of advanced technology. However, this approach may have a human-centric bias, ie, trying to understand ET entities through a distinctly human lens, and may not account for potential civilisations which could be completely different from ours, say researchers from the Arizona State University. In the new thought experiment, they propose a whole new way in which advanced aliens could potentially be communicating with other ET civilisations. Fireflies communicate using patterns of light flashes, which stand out from their environment and from other fireflies. Each firefly species has evolved to have flash patterns that are different from others, enabling members of a species to recognise each other. Even though fireflies do not understand what these flashes convey, their patterns can signal the presence of each firefly and its identity against a noisy natural background. Similarly, advanced aliens may also be flashing signals in a binary on/off flash pattern, which may not have any specific meaning, but could just stand out from the natural cosmic background of bright stars and galaxies, scientists say. “Extraterrestrial signals may also be identifiable not by their complexity or decodable content, but by the structural properties of the signal,” researchers write in the yet-to-be peer-reviewed study posted in arXiv. Scientists developed a firefly-inspired model to explore how intelligent aliens might generate signals that are distinct from their background, but do not carry any decoded meaning. One of the brightest background objects in the cosmos is a pulsar, which is a spinning neutron star that emits regular pulses of predictable and periodic radio waves. Researchers simulated signals from about 150 known pulsars and generated an artificial signal that stands out from such a pulsar background. They also accounted for the energy required to produce such a signal. This helped scientists estimate the kind of artificial signal most distinct from the pulsar background in space that could be produced by advanced aliens with reasonably low energy. Scientists found that artificial signals could be generated considerably more distinct from the pulsar population by an advanced alien civilisation. This means any detectable alien communication doesn't have to be meaningful to us but only needs to be unlikely to happen by chance in nature, researchers say. “Our model demonstrates that alien signals need not be inherently complicated nor need we decipher their meaning to identify them,” they write. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Extreme And Evil R-Rated 70s Supernatural Thriller Is Liminal, Uncanny, Horrifying
Source: giant freakin robot    Published: 2026-01-07 04:52:54

By Robert Scucci | Updated 34 seconds ago One of the reasons I've spent recent years latching onto the analog horror trend on YouTube is how the genre uses liminal space to generate unease. Series like The Backrooms and The Mandela Catalogue thrive because of the unsettling atmospheres they occupy, and films like Skinamarink are so sparsely decorated that they let your imagination do most of the heavy lifting. The problem is that there aren't a ton of feature-length films that really use liminal space to its fullest potential. At least, that's what I thought before feasting my eyes on 1974's Messiah of Evil. I have to give credit where it's due, as I first heard about Messiah of Evil after running a YouTube search for “Liminal Horror.” That rabbit hole led me to a channel called Nightmare Movies, which sold me on streaming the film after breaking it down so succinctly. If you're a fan of liminal horror and you've slept on Messiah of Evil like I had, it's in your best interest to check it out on Tubi. It's streaming there for free, and it will take you to a strange place in the uncanny valley that threatens to swallow you whole. I'm only going to touch on the most basic plot elements that Messiah of Evil has to offer, because the story is only half the battle here. The main thread follows Arletty Lang (Marianna Hill), who travels to the small beach town of Point Dune in hopes of reconnecting with her estranged father, Joseph (Royal Dano). Joseph is a troubled artist who has lived in the town for years, but has become increasingly unstable as of late. Arletty discovers letters from her father addressed to her that warn of a plague overtaking Point Dune. These writings also describe the increasingly vivid nightmares Joseph has been experiencing, which slowly bleed into something far more ominous. During her stay, Arletty encounters Thom (Michael Greer) and his two companions, Toni (Joy Bang) and Laura (Anitra Ford). While talking at Thom's motel, they have a run-in with a local vagrant named Charlie, who warns them about an upcoming blood moon. According to Charlie, this event marks the 100-year anniversary of the appearance of an entity known as the Dark Stranger, which ties directly into Joseph's paranoid letters. After Charlie ominously claims that her father is “one of them now,” Arletty's curiosity turns into alarm, pushing her to dig deeper into what's actually happening in Point Dune. Messiah of Evil's surface-level horror comes from the zombie-like trance the residents of Point Dune fall into as the film escalates. People who appear perfectly normal are suddenly shown feasting on raw meat in grocery stores, only to snap into pursuit once they spot someone who hasn't turned. For me, the liminal spaces these moments take place in make Messiah of Evil genuinely horrifying. I've always found empty versions of places that are meant to be crowded to be among the most unsettling settings imaginable, and Messiah of Evil fully commits to that idea. Gas stations, Ralphs grocery stores, movie theaters, and other familiar third places feel menacing specifically because of their emptiness as Arletty searches for answers about her father. Joseph's artwork lurking in the background makes you hypervigilant as a viewer, never quite sure whether those paintings are playing tricks on your eyes or watching you back. There's a constant sense that something is wrong just outside the frame. Much of that dread forms in your own head rather than being spelled out for you. The imagery does the heavy lifting here, not the exposition, which is why the specifics of the plot in Messiah of Evil matter far less than its cinematography and overall delivery. Messiah of Evil feels like that figure you think you see standing in your doorway as you drift off to sleep, when you're not entirely sure if it's a shadow on the wall or someone watching you. For nearly its entire runtime, the film sustains that feeling. The zombie attacks are just an added bonus. GFR SCORE Messiah of Evil, which is currently streaming for free on streaming services like, Tubi, PlutoTV, and Hoopla, is one of those movies that rewards multiple viewings. Watch it once for the general storyline, then revisit it purely for the liminal nightmare it occupies and thrives in. 2 days ago 2 days ago 3 days ago 2 hours ago 3 hours ago 4 hours ago
